text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

20.1	The Economic Commission for Europe (ECE) is responsible for facilitating economic integration and cooperation among its member States and promoting sustainable development and economic prosperity in the ECE region. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly and Economic and Social Council resolutions and decisions, including on the workplan on reform of ECE and the outcome of the review of the 2005 reform of ECE (resolutions 2006/38 and 2013/1, respectively), and Council resolution 36 (IV). The Commission provides a regional intergovernmental platform to promote sustainable approaches, solutions and innovation pertaining to economic integration and trade, transport and mobility, environmental protection and management of natural resources, forests and the forest industry, affordable and clean energy, competitiveness and public-private partnerships, emerging social and demographic challenges and land management, while strengthening member States’ capacities to measure progress towards the achievement of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and their access to timely and quality evidence for informed policymaking. ECE will support member States’ commitment to take bold, ambitious, accelerated, just and transformative actions to implement the 2030 Agenda, achieve the Sustainable Development Goals and leave no one behind, as reiterated in the Pact for the Future. Considering its regional nature and membership of 56 States, ECE remains uniquely positioned and will continue to leverage its core mandated functions, namely, policy dialogue, normative work and technical cooperation, in support of the realization of the ambitions of the peoples of the ECE region for a just and prosperous future for all. The support delivered by the Commission to member States is also provided through the regular programme of technical cooperation and Development Account projects.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

20.2	The overall strategy and proposed programme of work of the Commission has been elaborated to align with the commitments outlined in the Pact for the Future, including the Global Digital Compact, and remains anchored in multilateral frameworks, such as the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, the Programme of Action for Landlocked Developing Countries for the Decade 2024–2034 and the New Urban Agenda, which were adopted by Member States to tackle social and economic challenges through sustained and people-centred development. Furthermore, the high-level, cross-cutting theme proposed for adoption by the Commission at its seventy-first session, “Climate action and resilient infrastructure for a sustainable future”, guided the proposed programme of work of the ECE secretariat.

20.3	The execution of the strategy will be realized through the intergovernmental bodies of ECE, which comprise the Commission and its sectoral committees and which remain fundamental for the ability of the ECE secretariat to deliver the support sought by national Governments and other stakeholders in their efforts to accelerate progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals. In addition, as convener of the Regional Forum on Sustainable Development, ECE will continue to serve as a region-wide, multi-stakeholder platform for the review and follow-up of the Goals, peer-to-peer learning and the exchange of practical solutions for tackling development challenges in an accelerated manner. Operationally, the ECE secretariat will continue to further strengthen its working methods, in line with paragraph 73 (a) of the Pact for the Future, under action 45, for more agile, timely and impactful support to ECE member States.

20.4	In line with the principles of the reform of the United Nations development system, ECE will continue to serve as a platform for policy dialogue to address multi-country, transboundary and regional economic, social and environmental issues, with a specific focus on both central and local authorities, as well as other stakeholders, including civil society, youth representatives, academia and the business community. The normative work of the programme will focus on the development and implementation of international legal instruments, norms and standards in areas critical to sustainable development, and on the identification and dissemination of best practices within and beyond the region. Through technical cooperation in its areas of expertise, the programme will provide demand-driven specialized and integrated policy advice, and capacity-building aimed at expanding the use by its member States of normative work, facilitate the achievement of the Goals at the country level and achieve multiplier effects by targeting cross-border issues.

20.5	The strategy of the programme integrates sustainable development approaches and builds on synergies and the expected results of its eight subprogrammes. It leverages cross-sectoral synergies of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and collaboration across the eight subprogrammes by the ECE secretariat, the intergovernmental architecture of ECE and the broader expert community for multi-stakeholder engagement and action towards accelerating progress in achieving the Goals.

20.6	In 2026, the programme will continue to provide support to its member States in addressing the economic and environmental challenges of achieving the Goals, with a focus on the transition areas with significant catalytic and multiplier effects, including energy, food systems, digital transformations, climate change, biodiversity loss and pollution. ECE will actively contribute to the decade of action for the Goals in the region, with an enhanced focus on localization, and will follow up on the outcomes of the upcoming Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development and Second World Summit for Social Development, as applicable.

20.7	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, ECE will build on its close cooperation with international and regional organizations and other regional actors to exchange knowledge, develop joint initiatives and enhance collective impact. Partnerships with the private sector and civil society organizations, think tanks and the academic sector will be strengthened to facilitate ECE policy dialogue and normative work and to engage them in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda by member States.

20.8	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, ECE will continue to play a key role in coordinating regional United Nations system entities. As co-lead of the Regional Collaborative Platform for Europe and Central Asia, it will promote joint action and synergies among United Nations regional entities and their partners in addressing regional, cross-cutting policy issues, offering integrated policy advice and providing regional perspectives at the global level, including through issue-based coalitions. This work will build on continued strategic partnerships and joint initiatives established by ECE with other United Nations entities and international financial institutions. The United Nations Special Programme for the Economies of Central Asia, implemented jointly by ECE and the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, will serve as the major framework for cooperation with relevant stakeholders in Central Asia. At the country level, ECE will work closely with the resident coordinators and as part of the United Nations country teams to facilitate the implementation of joint programmes and projects in response to country demands, including by contributing to the planning (common country analyses), monitoring and implementation of the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks. The programme will also promote interregional (including South-South) and triangular cooperation.
20.9	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	Member States continue to guide intergovernmental processes, support the initiatives and give priority to regional and subregional cooperation and integration, with a view to achieving sustainable development;
(b)	All relevant stakeholders at the national level have the political will to cooperate in implementing ECE legal instruments, norms and standards;
(c)	Voluntary resources continue to be available.

20.10	ECE integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, in particular to support member States in the achievement of Sustainable Development Goal 5 and targets of the Goals relating to gender equality and women’s empowerment. Guided by the Commission’s policy and 2026 action plan on gender equality and the empowerment of women, all subprogrammes will continue to take concrete action with measurable outputs on mainstreaming a gender perspective into the Commission’s normative work and further promoting the participation of women in all initiatives. ECE will also prioritize technical cooperation projects that contribute towards gender equality.

20.11	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, ECE will continue to ensure that disability inclusion is mainstreamed into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. In line with its annual disability inclusion action plan, ECE will advance disability inclusion in the relevant normative instruments and good practices, as well as its programmes and projects.

children.text: Evaluation activities
20.14	The following evaluations completed in 2024 have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a)	Office of Internal Oversight Services synthesis review of evaluation results for regional economic commissions – contributions to economic development;
(b)	ECE evaluation of regular budget activities on the United Nations Framework Classification for Resources and the United Nations Resource Management System for the period 2020–2023;
(c)	Final evaluations of seven field and technical cooperation projects.

20.15	In response to the results of the evaluations referenced above, subprogramme 5, Sustainable energy, will deliver training events to further build capacity on the United Nations Framework Classification for Resources and the United Nations Resource Management System, issue a publication to further increase their visibility with both ECE and non-ECE member States, and launch projects to continue to develop, implement and disseminate them as part of the deliverables of subprogramme 5. The evaluations of field and technical cooperation projects informed the preparation of new such projects.

20.16	A programme-level evaluation of ECE data use and information management approaches during the period 2020–2025, which had previously been planned for 2025 but was deferred due to liquidity-related resource constraints, is planned for 2026.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Environment
Objective
20.17	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to improve environmental governance and performance for safeguarding the environment and health.
Strategy
20.18	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Support the implementation of outcomes of global and regional summits and conferences, and support and promote the implementation of multilateral environmental agreements, contributing to achieving Sustainable Development Goals 3, 6, 9, 11 to 13 and 15 to 17, through policy dialogue, normative work, capacity-building and the dissemination of environmental information (e.g., through the Shared Environmental Information System), good practices and lessons learned in the areas of air quality, water, industrial safety, public participation, impact assessment, environmental monitoring and assessment, environmental performance, education for sustainable development, and the mainstreaming of environmental concerns into other dimensions of sustainable development;

(b)	Support and promote the implementation of policy tools, including the ECE Environmental Performance Review Programme, contributing to achieving mainly Goals 6, 11 to 13 and 15; the ECE Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Programme, contributing to achieving mainly Goal 17; the ECE Strategy for Education for Sustainable Development, contributing to achieving Goals 4, 12 and 13; and the Transport, Health and Environment Pan-European Programme, contributing to achieving mainly Goals 3, 11, 13 and 17;
(c)	Promote synergies among ECE multilateral environmental agreements;
(d)	Conduct environmental performance reviews, assisting countries in the implementation of the recommendations from those reviews, and monitor the impact of the recommendations on national policies;

(e)	Using a country needs-based approach, support countries, with a focus on the Caucasus, Central Asia and Eastern and South-Eastern Europe, in environmental policymaking, monitoring, assessment and management, including by providing an intergovernmental decision-making platform, organizing capacity-building activities and providing advisory services;
(f)	Work with interested non-ECE countries, including those wishing to join the multilateral environmental agreements that are open to global accession;

(g)	Support member States in addressing emerging issues related to the work of the subprogramme, including those resulting from international and regional processes by, among others, providing advisory support, developing policy packages and/or recommendations and supporting countries in the development of region-wide approaches to such emerging issues (e.g., on sustainable infrastructure), including ensuring effective and inclusive access to information, public participation in decision-making and access to justice.
20.19	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Improved environmental governance and performance;
(b)	Strengthened integration of environmental concerns into member States’ sectoral policies;
(c)	More effective development and implementation of environmental legislation and policies;
(d)	Improved response to environmental challenges;
(e)	Enhanced participation, cross-border cooperation and effective international and national cooperation;
(f)	Strengthened implementation of multilateral environmental commitments and increased geographical coverage.
Programme performance in 2024
Youth empowered to drive sustainable development

20.20	Building on the implementation framework of the ECE Strategy for Education for Sustainable Development from 2021 to 2030, in 2024 the Government of Cyprus hosted a forum on the theme “Empowering youth for sustainable futures: entrepreneurship education and youth engagement”, in collaboration with ECE, the State Secretariat for Education, Research and Innovation of Switzerland and the United Nations Environment Programme. The forum, which featured several young leaders and entrepreneurs as speakers, addressed critical issues related to youth policy, education, empowerment and financing, underscoring the essential role of young people in driving sustainable development. The results of the discussions contributed to the Summit of the Future side event on the theme “Empowering youth for sustainable futures: intergenerational responsibility and skills for a just transition”, which facilitated intergenerational dialogue between youth, national Governments, experts in sustainability and education and the United Nations on the role of education in sustainable development and ways to equip youth with essential skills that align with evolving job market demands in sustainability sectors.

20.26	The series of pan-European environmental assessments provide up-to-date and policy-related information on the interactions between the environment and society and have been a consistent feature of the Environment for Europe process to date.
Lessons learned and planned change

20.27	The lesson for the subprogramme was that strengthening the environmental knowledge base in the region through environmental indicators and regular assessments can improve the understanding of the challenges the environment and society are and will be facing. In applying the lesson and in the context of the Tenth Environment for Europe Ministerial Conference, the subprogramme will further strengthen its approach to conducting environmental assessments and will include new indicators and up-to-date analysis as well as practical approaches to track and compare progress and inform policymaking. The subprogramme will also provide recommendations for action to prevent or reduce the implications for the environment and human health.

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Transport
Objective

20.30	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance an intraregionally and interregionally sustainable inland transport (road, rail, inland waterway and intermodality) system by making it safer, cleaner, more efficient, more inclusive and more affordable, both for freight transport and people’s mobility.
Strategy
20.31	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Service the Inland Transport Committee and its 21 working parties and 13 administrative committees, as well as the Committee of Experts on the Transport of Dangerous Goods and on the Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals of the Economic and Social Council and more than 50 formal and informal expert networks, accounting for the central role of the Inland Transport Committee in leading and coordinating its subsidiary bodies and its extended interregional geographical scope (following the endorsement of the Committee’s revised terms of reference by the Council in 2022), and promote the achievement of the objectives of the Committee’s strategy until 2030 and its Strategy on Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Inland Transport;

(b)	Administer the international regulatory framework for inland transport, which includes 61 United Nations legal instruments on safety, pollution, efficiency, multimodality and effectiveness, and ensure that the regulatory functions of the Inland Transport Committee are up to date with current technologies and transport innovations – such as intelligent transport systems, autonomous vehicles, digitization of customs and transport documents, and electric vehicles – and all legal instruments are open to all United Nations Member States, as appropriate, by developing new and updating existing legal instruments, as necessary, including maintaining the database of international regulatory frameworks for inland transport;

(c)	Provide an intergovernmental policy dialogue platform at the annual sessions of the Inland Transport Committee to review emerging challenges and emergency situations; support consensus-building in favour of regional and interregional connectivity, and climate change mitigation and adaptation, among other matters, including through the adoption of strategies, action plans, high-level statements or resolutions on harmonized actions by member States and Contracting Parties in order to enable the full implementation of the Committee’s mandate;

(d)	Analyse and provide technical assistance and capacity-building on accession to and implementation of legal instruments, at the request of member States and Contracting Parties within and beyond the region;

(e)	Facilitate global improvements in road safety, through policy dialogue and by contributing to the work of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Road Safety and the operation of the United Nations Road Safety Fund, in cooperation with other international organizations, and provide capacity-building and advisory assistance with regard to promoting legal instruments, calls for proposals and other related activities, as appropriate;

(f)	Support the efforts of member States to respond to and recover from emergency situations, including pandemics, and foster the functioning and development of national, regional and international inclusive transport systems and the implementation of the sustainable development agenda;

(g)	Promote knowledge-sharing and cooperation among Governments and key stakeholders, raise awareness of emerging issues and best responses, contribute to the improved monitoring and measuring of the Sustainable Development Goals, facilitate the adaptation of legally binding instruments and frameworks to new realities, and prepare new guidance materials.
20.32	The above-mentioned work is expected to contribute to the achievement of Goals 3, 5, 6 to 9 and 11 to 13 and result in:
(a)	Improvements in sustainable mobility, and in monitoring and measuring the Goals;
(b)	Safer, cleaner, more efficient, more inclusive and more affordable multimodal inland transport systems for Contracting Parties to the United Nations inland transport conventions;
(c)	Enhanced efforts towards net-zero emissions by 2050, guided by a strategy for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in inland transport;
(d)	More efficient and resilient cross-border flows of goods and people regionally and globally;
(e)	Enhanced intergovernmental cooperation in emergency situations and minimized disruptions to the continued implementation and updating of United Nations inland transport conventions.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced intergovernmental cooperation to accelerate the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from inland transport

20.33	Inland transport is responsible for 72 per cent of the transport sector’s total emissions, driven primarily by road transport. In 2024, the Inland Transport Committee adopted its Strategy on Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Inland Transport, to support the sector to take urgent climate action and align its climate change mitigation strategies with those for civil aviation by the International Civil Aviation Organization and maritime transport by the International Maritime Organization. The subprogramme prepared a draft strategy with inputs from the Committee’s working parties and coordinated intergovernmental negotiations during 2023 and 2024, which resulted in its adoption by the Committee at its eighty-sixth session (ECE/TRANS/344, annex I).
20.34	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 20.6).

Result 2: increased accessions to core road safety conventions as an initial step to contribute to fewer worldwide road accident fatalities and injuries – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
20.37	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 491 accessions to core United Nations road safety conventions and 10 events on road safety convention implementation, which met the planned target.

Result 3: enhanced regulatory framework for sustainable inland transport systems – Proposed programme plan for 2026

20.39	The subprogramme’s work on enhancing the regulatory framework in recent years has led to the development of updates to legal instruments, policy advice and recommendations to support the efforts of member States and Contracting Parties to further develop sustainable inland transport systems within and outside the region.
Lessons learned and planned change

20.40	The lesson for the subprogramme was that its approach and focus need to be better aligned with the growing demand of member States and the potential for expanding the geographical scope. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will scale up its efforts to support the development of sustainable inland transport systems in the region and internationally, improve their environmental performance (as a means to facilitate the circular economy and the sustainable use of natural resources) and reduce emissions, and enhance efficiency, connectivity and accessibility for all, including persons with disabilities, through the digitization of documents and procedures and the promotion of automated vehicles. The subprogramme will also enhance its regulatory support for the implementation of the Inland Transport Committee’s strategy until 2030 and its Strategy on Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Inland Transport by developing tools, analysing trends and challenges and encouraging greater participation of States from outside the region.
20.41	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.IV).

children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Statistics
Objective

20.43	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance official statistics at the national and international levels for evidence-based policymaking and assessing progress towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and to ensure the coordination of statistical activities in the ECE region under the Conference of European Statisticians.
Strategy

20.44	The strategy of the subprogramme is guided by the priorities and needs of member States and is based on the core interlinked functions: the streamlining of international statistical work in the ECE region through policy dialogue; methodological work to develop and promote guidelines and recommendations to enhance the quality of statistics; and the statistical capacity development of ECE member States with less developed statistical systems.
20.45	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Promote in-depth statistical dialogue at the Conference of European Statisticians and expert meetings;

(b)	Launch regional and country-specific initiatives related to methodological work to develop and disseminate statistical models, guidelines and recommendations to enhance the quality of statistics, to support modernization of national statistical offices and their changing role to become data stewards, and to promote the use of official statistics;
(c)	Maintain and develop the ECE statistical database;

(d)	Establish and strengthen partnerships between geospatial experts and statisticians to support the integration of statistical and geospatial information, in cooperation with statistical departments of other regional entities, as well as international specialized agencies active in the region;

(e)	Facilitate the exchange of experiences and good practices in population and housing censuses, price statistics and environment statistics, allowing for improved timeliness and granularity of official statistics;

(f)	Provide support to countries in planning and conducting their census and developing their statistical capacity, including cross-cutting topics such as statistics for the Sustainable Development Goals, statistical legislation, data collection, integration and dissemination, and human resource management.
20.46	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Improved statistical methodology and capacity of member States to measure and monitor the Sustainable Development Goals;

(b)	Member States using innovative and efficient approaches to conducting censuses that result in the improved cost-efficiency, coverage, accuracy, comparability and timeliness of dissemination of the census results;
(c)	Improved capacity by member States to provide the statistics necessary to develop evidence-based policies to advance progress against the Goals.
Programme performance in 2024
More efficient population and housing censuses

20.47	Population and housing censuses provide the baseline information used to plan public infrastructure and services, and to produce Sustainable Development Goal indicators and many other statistics where population is the denominator. The subprogramme supports countries in preparing for, conducting, processing and disseminating data from their population and housing censuses. To help to support more efficient census-taking using administrative sources, the regional census recommendations for the 2020 round (2015) were accompanied by the Guidelines on the Use of Registers and Administrative Data for Population and Housing Censuses (2018) and the Guidelines for Assessing the Quality of Administrative Sources for Use in Censuses (2021).
20.48	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 20.8).
Table 20.8
Performance measure: number of member States that have used data from administrative sources for their census

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: improved environmental statistics and indicators in the Economic Commission for Europe region – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

20.49	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 26 member States actively improving environmental statistics and indicators by participating in the Joint Task Force on Environmental Statistics and Indicators, which did not meet the planned target of 28 member States for 2024. The target was not met due to limitations to organizing hybrid meetings which would have enabled more countries to attend.
20.50	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.V).
Figure 20.V
Performance measure: number of countries improving environmental statistics and indicators through the Joint Task Force on Environmental Statistics and Indicators (annual)
Result 2: Economic Commission for Europe statistical database for improved research and decision-making – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
20.51	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 1,462,621 downloads from the ECE statistical database, which exceeded the planned target of 967,627.
20.52	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.VI).
Figure 20.VI
Performance measure: number of downloads from the Economic Commission for Europe statistical database (annual)
Result 3: improved reporting for monitoring the Sustainable Development Goals – Proposed programme plan for 2026

20.53	The availability of indicators for monitoring the Goals supports decision-making and resource allocation by member States. The subprogramme supports national statistical offices to facilitate country-led reporting of statistics for the Goals, by developing guidance and tools for assessing progress and data availability, analysing the lessons that national statistical offices have learned from this process, and developing training material. ECE also continues to enhance its regional platform for data on these indicators and maintain a knowledge hub on statistics for the Sustainable Development Goals.
Lessons learned and planned change

20.54	The lesson for the subprogramme was that strong engagement of national experts in the development of international guidance and tools can strengthen their uptake at the national level and thereby the production of Sustainable Development Goal indicators. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will enhance the engagement of national experts, including by facilitating peer exchanges of experience and providing self-assessment tools to assess gaps and potential improvements of data reported on the Goal indicators.
20.55	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.VII).
Figure 20.VII
Performance measure: percentage of Sustainable Development Goal indicators that have sufficient data for assessing progress at the level of the Economic Commission for Europe region (annual)

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Economic cooperation and integration
Objective
20.57	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen policies on innovation, competitiveness and public-private partnerships for sustainable development in the ECE region.
Strategy

20.58	The strategy of the subprogramme is based on the implementation of three core interlinked functions in the subprogramme’s two areas of work (innovation and competitiveness policies; and public-private partnerships): international policy dialogue; normative and analytical work; and capacity-building and the sharing of best practices and lessons learned.
20.59	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Support member States in creating a conducive business environment by developing good practices to inform innovation policy reforms in order to drive sustainable development, including through on-demand analyses of national innovation systems, policies and institutions; and through capacity-building workshops and seminars at the national and subregional levels;

(b)	Build the capacity of member States in creating regulatory frameworks and public-private partnership project pipelines that can help to close the Sustainable Development Goals infrastructure financing gap, including through:
(i)	The promotion of innovative modalities for financing, developing and managing critical infrastructure;
(ii)	The development of international guidelines and standards to design public-private partnership projects and legal and regulatory frameworks;
(iii)	The use, on demand, of a methodology to evaluate and score public-private partnership projects in support of sustainable development;
(iv)	Cooperation with multilateral platforms for sustainable infrastructure (including SOURCE);

(c)	Focus some of its policy dialogues, analyses and recommendations, standards and capacity-building on addressing economic challenges through innovation policies and public-private partnership infrastructure projects that can facilitate innovation and develop infrastructure to make economies more resilient and sustainable.
20.60	The above-mentioned work will help member States to make progress towards achieving Sustainable Development Goals 8, 9, 12 and 17 and is expected to result in:
(a)	Improved innovation-related policies and institutions for sustainable development;
(b)	The improved design and operation of public-private partnerships that contribute to sustainable development projects.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States equipped to develop infrastructure projects in support of the Goals

20.61	In 2021, the subprogramme developed the Public-Private Partnerships and Infrastructure Evaluation and Rating System (PIERS) for member States to self-assess infrastructure projects. The methodology enables member States to assess public-private partnerships for infrastructure on their contributions to the Goals against the backdrop of the three pillars of sustainable development (economic, environmental and social) by providing valuable insights on their sustainability and ways to improve it. Subsequently, the subprogramme built institutional and human capacities in requesting member States to utilize PIERS to develop infrastructure projects that are not only bankable but also sustainable. As of 2024, the work resulted in eight member States having the proficiency to utilize the PIERS methodology to ensure that public-private partnerships contribute to the Goals and remain attractive to potential investors.
20.62	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.VIII).
Figure 20.VIII

Performance measure: number of United Nations Member States that are proficient in the use of the Public-Private Partnerships and Infrastructure Evaluation and Rating System methodology to ensure that public-private partnerships contribute to the Goals and are attractive to potential investors (cumulative)

20.65	The subprogramme’s work contributed to a cumulative total of 253 public-private partnership infrastructure projects having been assessed as Sustainable Development Goal-compliant using the PIERS methodology, which exceeded the planned target of 250 public-private partnership infrastructure projects.

Result 3: improved innovation policies and initiatives for sustainable development – Proposed programme plan for 2026

20.67	The subprogramme has supported requesting ECE programme countries with in-depth analyses of their innovation policies, resulting in detailed recommendations for policy reforms, with tailored training programmes to build capacity.
Lessons learned and planned change

20.68	The lesson for the subprogramme was twofold: (a) there is a need to meet the increasing demand for innovation policy analysis, advice and capacity-building; and (b) even in the countries covered, the full potential of innovation to deliver breakthroughs for a better and more sustainable future remains underdeveloped. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will support additional programme countries in the region with innovation policy analysis, advice and capacity-building and will further tailor the provision of technical assistance to programme countries, to enable them to implement relevant actions and decisions contained in the Pact for the Future.

children.text: Subprogramme 5 – Sustainable energy
Objective

20.71	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to ensure secure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the carbon footprint of the energy sector in the region.
Strategy

20.72	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will support international policy dialogue and cooperation among Governments, energy industries and other stakeholders to foster sustainable energy development; develop and deploy ECE policy recommendations, norms, standards, guidelines and tools on energy-related issues; and provide capacity-building and assistance to member States, at their request, through training programmes, advisory services and technical cooperation projects. Through its work, the subprogramme will contribute to ECE work on cross-sectoral collaboration areas and priorities relating to the circular economy. Specifically, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Further develop normative instruments (such as best practices and principles), awareness-raising campaigns and the deployment of ECE tools through workshops, seminars and technical projects to assist member States to meet their commitments to the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement with regard to reducing their environmental footprint related to energy, accelerating the deep transformation of the energy sector to meet future needs, ensuring the sustainable management of resources and assessing options to ensure energy for sustainable development;
(b)	Promote policy dialogue and cooperation among member States, regional entities and other partners on sustainable energy issues;
(c)	Provide technical assistance and guidance on energy transitions in the context of sustainable development, disseminate best practices and improve information-sharing;

(d)	Promote collaboration among private and public stakeholders that are key to implementing national and regional policies, including with regard to normative instruments and their deployment and dissemination;
(e)	Coordinate and promote efforts related to energy resilience across the ECE region and continue shaping the Platform on Resilient Energy Systems for inclusive dialogue and informed policymaking;

(f)	Explore and increase understanding on energy-related climate financing in the region, including policies and mechanisms for increasing financing for low- and zero-carbon technologies, the critical raw materials needed for low-carbon and low-emissions transformations and sustainable infrastructure projects;

(g)	Support countries across the region in applying the United Nations Framework Classification for Resources and the United Nations Resource Management System to ensure sustainable development of their natural resources, including access to and development of critical raw materials;

(h)	Support ECE member States in enhancing their understanding of the benefits of low- and zero-carbon technology interplay for more resilient energy systems across the ECE region by deploying the ECE Carbon Neutrality Toolkit while periodically verifying and updating data;

(i)	Support ECE member States in broadening and accelerating the deployment of energy efficiency measures across buildings, industry, transport and other end-use sectors while embracing sector-wide digitalization;

(j)	Support and guide ECE member States in their efforts to accurately measure and report methane emissions from the energy sector and the related extractive industries, and to effectively mitigate those emissions by detecting and repairing leaks from the installed infrastructure and by capturing and destroying or utilizing gas from active, closed and abandoned coal mines;

(k)	Support ECE member States in embracing the concept of “just transition”, being an integrated approach to sustainable development, which brings together social progress, environmental protection and economic success into a framework of democratic governance; and increase ECE member States’ understanding of that concept and its complexity and improve their capacity to plan and implement transformation strategies in accordance with its principles.
20.73	The above-mentioned work is expected to contribute to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 7, 12 and 13 and result in:
(a)	More effective integration of sustainable energy across national policies and normative frameworks in support of the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement;

(b)	Enhanced dialogue and cooperation among energy actors to boost transformational investment in the energy sector and, consequently, accelerate the modernization of the energy system to meet countries’ sustainable development and climate commitments;

(c)	Improved access of member States to frameworks and tools required for integrated and sustainable resource management and governance that aid the progress towards a more circular economy and contribute to the food-water-energy nexus, fostering equitable and responsible resource management on a global scale;
(d)	Increased systemic efficiencies and digitalization of energy system networks;

(e)	Increased understanding and implementation of climate-friendly policies and mechanisms by member States, which are aimed at addressing issues such as financing for low- and zero-carbon technologies and sustainable infrastructure, and critical raw materials needed for such transformations;

(f)	Improved capacity of ECE member States to design and implement policies setting up effective mechanisms for accurate measurement and reporting of methane emissions from the energy sector and the related extractive industries, as well as for their effective mitigation;

(g)	Improved understanding of a “just transition” approach and increased capacity of ECE member States for its effective application in the context of national energy transition strategies, at both the planning and the implementation stages.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States commit to reducing methane emissions

20.74	To mobilize action for reducing methane emissions, the subprogramme co-organized the Global Methane Forum 2024. The event brought together over 800 decision makers, practitioners and experts from over 50 Member States. The subprogramme, taking into account Economic and Social Council resolution 2023/18, also provided Member States with guidance on setting up national monitoring, reporting and verification programmes, which are necessary to properly assess the scale of methane emissions and identify opportunities for mitigation. Six online and seven on-site capacity-building events were organized to disseminate best practices, facilitate knowledge transfer and cooperation and advocate for the importance of methane mitigation. The advocacy and technical guidance provided by the subprogramme contributed to two additional ECE member States (Azerbaijan and Tajikistan) joining the Global Methane Pledge and enabled eight United Nations Member States to develop and present road maps for reducing methane emissions.

children.text: Result 3: increased adoption of electric mobility for a sustainable energy transition – Proposed programme plan for 2026

20.80	E-mobility adoption can accelerate the transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources in transportation, reducing carbon emissions and promoting more resilient energy systems. The subprogramme provides technical assistance to Member States to improve capacity for e-mobility adoption and enhance the expertise of policymakers in supporting the adoption of electric vehicles for the energy transition.
Lessons learned and planned change

20.81	The lesson learned for the subprogramme was that there is increased demand from Member States for technical assistance related to increasing challenges related to infrastructure, energy management and integration into the grid associated with the rapid growth in e-mobility. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will organize workshops and dialogues on supporting e-mobility adoption and sharing best practices on the integration of e-mobility into energy systems.

children.text: Subprogramme 6 – Trade
Objective

20.84	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen trade facilitation and electronic business, regulatory cooperation and standardization policies, agricultural quality standards and trade-related economic cooperation for an increased impact on sustainable development in the ECE region and beyond.
Strategy

20.85	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will support international policy dialogue on reducing regulatory and procedural barriers to trade, including those caused by cumbersome trade procedures and paperwork, by differences in trade procedures, standards and documents, or by divergent regulatory approaches and product standards; facilitate the development of standards and recommendations in the areas of trade facilitation and electronic business, agricultural quality standards and regulatory cooperation; and provide capacity-building and enable the sharing of best practices and lessons learned. Specifically, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Promote simple, transparent and effective processes for sustainable, inclusive and resilient global trade through its normative work to develop standards and recommendations in the areas of trade facilitation and electronic business;

(b)	Facilitate international policy dialogue on establishing digital trading environments and on compliance with the multilateral trading system requirements, including the dissemination of standards, recommendations and guidelines;

(c)	Promote the circular economy and the sustainable use of natural resources, sustainable and resilient value chains and the enhanced traceability of supply chains (e.g., minimizing waste and maximizing the use of natural resources towards the circular economy) through studies, policy dialogues, capacity-building and technology-based pilot initiatives such as blockchain-based traceability for relevant value chains;

(d)	Strengthen regulatory cooperation and promote standards and best practices in regulatory frameworks, risk management, conformity assessment and market surveillance to facilitate a predictable and harmonized regulatory environment;

(e)	Provide practical ways forward for standards bodies wishing to mainstream a gender perspective into standards and throughout the quality infrastructure for trade, notably through capacity-building, sharing of best practices and dissemination;

(f)	Promote up-to-date agricultural quality standards and explanatory guidelines through its normative work and promote awareness of food loss reduction through policy dialogues, partnerships with international organizations and initiatives to address food loss and waste;

(g)	Identify regulatory and procedural barriers to trade and assist Governments in setting action-oriented recommendations for implementing the instruments developed by the subprogramme through analytical evidence-based studies, including with the objective of pursuing ECE-wide cross-cutting priority themes;

(h)	Deepen its international policy dialogue, normative, technical assistance and capacity-building activities on the digitalization of trade processes in order to support efforts to harness the power of trade for sustainable development.
20.86	The above-mentioned work is expected to contribute to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 2, 5, 8, 9, 12 and 17 and to result in:
(a)	Increased implementation of simplified trade processes, and the digitalization of member States’ trading environments, leading to greater productivity;
(b)	Increased transparency and traceability of the value chains and reduction of waste, promoting sustainable consumption and production patterns;
(c)	Increased uptake of international standards, including ECE agricultural quality standards, by countries to enable the implementation of internationally harmonized regulatory processes;
(d)	Improved gender equality in trade through the increased participation of women traders;

(e)	Enhanced digitalization of trade procedures (e.g., progress towards the adoption of trade-related digital services such as Single Window) to support public and private sectors’ efforts in member States to facilitate trade.
Programme performance in 2024
Trade-related policies enable transition to a more circular economy

20.87	To support member States with accelerating the transition to a more circular economy, the subprogramme has worked to assist national authorities in filling gaps and creating synergies among many initiatives, addressing key areas of trade policy, including food loss and waste reduction, traceability of value chains and related institutional arrangements. Since 2022, gap analyses have been undertaken in three countries that were key inputs to the formulation of circular economy road maps, action plans and related national strategies in priority sectors and thematic areas, with a focus on the following: (a) fostering international production networks and value chains that comply with circularity principles and improve the ability of customers to trace the products they buy, contributing to increased transparency; and (b) addressing the responsible management of waste by helping countries to substantially reduce waste generation through prevention, reduction, recycling and reuse in line with ECE guidance (e.g., code of good practice for reducing losses in the handling of fresh fruit and vegetables along international supply chains).
20.88	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.XII).
Figure 20.XII
Performance measure: number of national road maps for transitioning to a more circular economy that are informed by Economic Commission for Europe guidance (cumulative)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: mainstreaming a gender perspective into standards development organizations – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

20.89	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 86 standards development organizations that have committed themselves to implementing the ECE Declaration for Gender Responsive Standards and Standards Development, which exceeded the planned target of 85.
20.90	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.XIII).
Figure 20.XIII

Performance measure: number of standards development organizations that have committed themselves to implementing the Economic Commission for Europe Declaration for Gender Responsive Standards and Standards Development (cumulative)
Result 2: enhanced digitalization of trade – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

20.91	The subprogramme’s work contributed to an average implementation rate of 82 per cent of paperless trade and an average implementation rate of 55 per cent of cross-border paperless trade among ECE member States, which met the planned target.
20.92	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.XIV).
Figure 20.XIV
Performance measure: average implementation rate of trade facilitation measures in the Economic Commission for Europe region
(Percentage)

Note: The data are captured every two years through the United Nations Global Survey on Digital and Sustainable Trade Facilitation (https://www.untfsurvey.org/), conducted most recently in 2023. Data for 2024 reflect achievements in 2023.
Result 3: improved transparency and traceability of value chains in critical sectors – Proposed programme plan for 2026

20.93	The rise in consumer awareness of the impacts of irresponsible production patterns has led several jurisdictions to adopt regulations mandating corporations to exercise due diligence along their supply chains. The subprogramme produced policy recommendations and guidelines, and piloted information exchange standards using blockchain technology to help producers to track their sustainability performance and achieve verifiable claims for products placed on markets. The sustainable value chains traceability and transparency toolbox includes the “Sustainability Pledge” call to action for industry actors to commit to measurable actions.
Lessons learned and planned change

20.94	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the subprogramme’s global orientation and expertise can be further leveraged to advance the traceability and transparency of value chains in a global and fragmented context. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will develop a global United Nations transparency protocol, supporting the interoperability of information exchange systems for digital product passports, and will further promote the Sustainability Pledge, in line with objective 4 of the Global Digital Compact, to advance responsible, equitable and interoperable data governance approaches.
20.95	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.XV).
Figure 20.XV
Performance measure: number of industry actors that have submitted pledges for the traceability and transparency of sustainable value chains (cumulative)
Note: Pledges refers to the number of pledges submitted. Partners refers to organizations involved in the pledges. Some of the pledges are submitted by a consortium or group of partners.

children.text: Subprogramme 7 – Forests and the forest industry
Objective

20.97	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen the sustainable management of trees and forests and enhance the contribution of forests and forest products to sustainable development, climate action and biodiversity in the ECE region.
Strategy
20.98	The strategy of the subprogramme is based on core interlinked functions, namely, analytical and normative work, international policy dialogue, capacity-building and communication.
20.99	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Promote cooperation for sustainable forest management, forest landscape restoration, sustainable use of forest products and services, linkages between sustainable food systems and forests, and urban and peri-urban forestry;

(b)	Collect, validate and disseminate information, research and analysis related to sustainable forest management and the sustainable production, consumption and trade of wood products, including wood energy;

(c)	Facilitate the exchange of national and subnational experiences and best practices and monitor progress on achieving sustainable forest management, including trade-related matters, which will help member States to measure progress towards achieving the relevant Sustainable Development Goals and the United Nations strategic plan for forests 2017–2030;
(d)	Organize capacity-building seminars and webinars and prepare dedicated publications on the forest sector and wood energy, including on crisis response and solutions for more resilient economies.
20.100	The subprogramme will carry out its work in partnership with the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) and other relevant organizations and processes.
20.101	The above-mentioned work is expected to contribute to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 7, 11 to 13 and 15 and result in:

(a)	The strengthened ability of member States to sustainably manage healthy forest ecosystems, to provide important ecosystem goods and services to benefit society, including climate mitigation and adaptation;
(b)	Increased and more efficient use of sustainable forest products that contribute to the circular economy and the sustainable use of natural resources;

(c)	The integration of forest resources and products into planning and recovery from economic, health and environmental shocks, to increase the resilience of member States and their most vulnerable persons.
Programme performance in 2024
New data and information on the state and management of boreal forests

20.102 	Boreal forests, the vast majority of which are in the ECE region, comprise 27 per cent of the global forest area. They play an important role in sustaining the global ecological equilibrium, and their sustainable management can balance competing needs and strengthen long-term forest resilience. The subprogramme has worked with member States and partners from the boreal region to gather information on their progress towards sustainable forest management. The new data set with information submitted for the first time by all boreal member States is the most comprehensive new source for evidence-based management of this globally, regionally and nationally important biome.
20.103	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.XVI).
Figure 20.XVI

Performance measure: information on forests and progress towards sustainable forest management in the boreal region, as measured by the percentage of Economic Commission for Europe member States with boreal forest replying to the Commission’s survey on boreal forests (cumulative)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: cities and towns commit themselves to expanding sustainable urban and peri-urban forest cover – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

20.104	The subprogramme’s work contributed to a cumulative total of 91 cities from 36 countries that made pledges and commitments to increasing sustainable urban tree and forest cover, which exceeded the planned target of 80 cities and 32 countries.
20.105	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.XVII).
Figure 20.XVII
Performance measure: number of cities and towns making pledges and commitments to increasing sustainable urban tree and forest cover (cumulative)
Result 2: evidence-based planning and action for the sustainable production and consumption of forest products – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

20.106	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 59 assessments of wood-based commodities and 12 member States that reported on the assessments’ use, which exceeded the planned target of 55 assessments and 10 member States.
20.107	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.XVIII).
Figure 20.XVIII

Performance measure: number of assessments of wood-based commodities, regarding their production, trade and consumption, and number of member States that report the use of information from these assessments (cumulative)
Abbreviation: n/a, not applicable.
Result 3: increased access to data on forests and the forest industry – Proposed programme plan for 2026

20.108	Both forests and the forest industry are closely linked with efforts to deliver sustainable development, climate and biodiversity goals. The subprogramme gathers data on forests and the forest industry to facilitate evidence-based decisions by policymakers and to inform the broader public. This approach underpins effective policymaking and action for managing forests sustainably to maximize their contribution to the environment, society and the economy.
Lessons learned and planned change

20.109	The lesson for the subprogramme was that data collection frameworks needed to be enhanced to reflect the evolving context and meet emerging data requirements and to ensure the utility of data for decision makers. In applying this lesson, the subprogramme will further strengthen efforts to enhance data collection tools and will update data requirements to help to maximize usefulness for policymakers. The subprogramme will also continue to build the capacity of national focal points to support the timely submission of good-quality statistical data that respond to the needs of policymakers and other data users.
20.110	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 20.XIX).
Figure 20.XIX

(Number of replies to the most recent questionnaires in each series)

children.text: Subprogramme 8 – Housing, land management and population
Objective

20.112	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen member State-owned and city-level programmes and policies promoting decent, adequate, affordable, energy-efficient and healthy housing for all, smart sustainable cities, sustainable urban development and land management, and to advance evidence-based population and social cohesion policies.
Strategy
20.113	The subprogramme comprises two components: (a) housing and land management; and (b) population.

20.114	The strategy of the subprogramme is based on core interlinked functions, namely, international policy dialogue, normative work, and capacity-building and the sharing of best practices and lessons learned in all areas of the subprogramme’s work.
20.115	To contribute to the objective, the housing and land management component of the subprogramme will:

(a)	Support member States’ national, regional and local governments and other key stakeholders in the review of progress in achieving Sustainable Development Goals 3, 5, 7, 9, 11 and 12, and build their capacities for the implementation of measures to accelerate the achievement of the Goals through technical assistance projects, thematic studies, training, exchange of experiences and best practices and policy advice on: affordable, energy-efficient and decent housing for all; housing finance; smart sustainable cities, digitalization in cities and innovative financial mechanisms for cities; land administration and management, including informal settlements; and urban strategies and programmes that integrate climate change measures and promote the climate neutrality of buildings;

(b)	Support local governments in the development of evidence-based policies on sustainable housing and urban development through the application of the ECE/International Telecommunication Union key performance indicators on smart sustainable cities, indicators on urban economic resilience and the United Nations system-wide urban monitoring framework; and in the preparation of smart sustainable cities profiles and voluntary local reviews based on the assessments of achievement of the Goals;

(c)	Provide assistance to national and local governments in the development of evidence-based urban and housing policies through the preparation of country profiles on urban development, housing and land management;

(d)	Support the strengthening of the capacities of national Governments and local ones in the design, implementation and monitoring of urban resilience plans and sustainable urban infrastructure development projects, including those that provide support to the most vulnerable persons, especially those in informal settlements;

(e)	Promote multi-stakeholder partnerships and innovative financing instruments to unlock further financing and partnerships for the implementation of these plans and projects, in collaboration with the Geneva United Nations Charter Centres of Excellence;
(f)	Subject to approval by the ECE Executive Committee, organize the sixth Forum of Mayors to discuss the challenges for sustainable housing and urban development.
20.116	To contribute to the objective, the population component of the subprogramme will:
(a)	Continue to facilitate cooperation among member States, regional agencies and other partners;

(b)	Support national and regional review and follow-up activities to assess progress in implementing the Madrid International Plan of Action on Ageing and its Regional Implementation Strategy by providing a platform for intergovernmental policy debate on matters related to mainstreaming ageing, and facilitate communication with a wider network of experts and non-governmental organizations;

(c)	Coordinate data collection on ageing indicators, including intergenerational and sex-disaggregated data, as well as policy-oriented research on ageing and intergenerational and gender relations, to support evidence-based policymaking and the monitoring of the implementation of the Madrid International Plan of Action on Ageing and its Regional Implementation Strategy;
(d)	Support the development of national capacities for policy formulation and mainstreaming ageing through policy discussions, policy briefs and the showcasing of good practices from member States.
20.117	The above-mentioned work in the area of housing and land management is expected to contribute to the achievement of Goal 11 and, to a lesser extent, Goals 3, 5, 7, 9 and 12, and result in:

(a)	Improved national and local policies for housing affordability, adequacy and accessibility for all; the energy efficiency and climate neutrality of buildings; and sustainable and resilient urban development;

(b)	Increased capacity of national and local governments for the development of housing and urban development policies and programmes, which integrate the concepts of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Geneva UN Charter on Sustainable Housing and the action plan entitled Place and Life in the ECE – A Regional Action Plan 2030: Tackling Challenges from the COVID-19 Pandemic, Climate and Housing Emergencies in the Region, City, Neighbourhood and Homes, as well as relevant best practices, including those developed and shared by the Geneva UN Charter Centres of Excellence;

(c)	Improved understanding by city authorities of their socioeconomic development priorities through the preparation of smart sustainable cities profiles and voluntary local reviews of the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, based on the revised guidelines for the development of voluntary local reviews in the ECE region and using ECE/International Telecommunication Union key performance indicators for smart sustainable cities, urban economic resilience indicators and a United Nations system-wide urban monitoring framework;

(d)	Increased capacity of land administration authorities to develop national land administration and management systems based on thematic studies and capacity-building activities in land administration and management;
(e)	More effective local urban development and housing policies and related resilience plans, in particular for people living in informal settlements.
20.118	The above-mentioned work in the area of population is expected to contribute to the achievement of Goals 1, 3 to 5, 8, 10, 11, 16 and 17 and result in:
(a)	Demonstrated progress by member States in mainstreaming ageing across all policy fields and governance levels;
(b)	Enhanced capacities of member States in mainstreaming ageing across all policy fields and governance levels;
(c)	Policy approaches adopted by member States that advance the rights and dignity of older persons and their contribution to a sustainable and inclusive society for all ages.
Programme performance in 2024
Mental health of older persons: increased awareness, strengthened knowledge and exchange of policy strategies among member States

20.119	Recognizing that a significant share of older persons in the ECE region are affected by mental health conditions, member States committed to invest in strategies and activities to strengthen the mental health of older persons, improve the protection of older persons with mental impairments, and ensure their participation, dignity and quality of life, in line with the Rome Ministerial Declaration on Ageing of 2022. In support of their efforts, in 2024 the subprogramme published a policy brief and facilitated a regional policy dialogue on the issue to raise awareness, build knowledge and facilitate the exchange of relevant policy strategies, resulting in 11 member States sharing national experiences.
20.120	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 20.18).
Table 20.18
Performance measure

children.text: Result 3: acceleration of Sustainable Development Goal localization by local and regional governments – Proposed programme plan for 2026

20.125	With increasing urbanization, cities play an important role in achieving the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Voluntary local reviews support local and regional governments to monitor and report on progress towards the implementation of the Goals. The subprogramme has supported localization of the Goals by updating guidelines and facilitating peer-to-peer dialogue on the development of voluntary local reviews.
Lessons learned and planned change

20.126	The lesson for the subprogramme was that piloting the guidelines in select cities before full implementation was essential to identify context-specific challenges, assess feasibility and refine guidelines based on practical insights. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme utilized the results of pilot testing to update the guidelines, and will provide practical, hands-on guidance and good practice on the development of voluntary local reviews while continuing to address emerging feedback from end users, including on data and indicators.

Other changes

20.132	As shown in table 20.26 (1), resource changes reflect a net increase of $7,700, which relates to an increase under programme support that reflects a higher standard price for the core software package for non-field personnel outside of United Nations Headquarters. Other changes also reflect the within-component cost-neutral redeployment of resources between experts and consultants, mainly within executive direction and management.
Extrabudgetary resources

20.133	As reflected in tables 20.26 (2) and 20.27 (2), extrabudgetary resources amount to $26,529,900. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 7 posts (1 D-1, 2 P-4, 1 P-3, 3 GS (OL)) to perform mainly the functions required to support the delivery of technical cooperation projects and activities approved by ECE governing bodies. In addition, non-post resources would be used for capacity-building and technical support in relation to the ECE programme of work.
20.134	The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of the Executive Committee of ECE and the governing bodies of the conventions.
Executive direction and management

20.135	The executive direction and management component comprises the Office of the Executive Secretary, the Sustainable Development Unit and the Information Unit. It also includes the Programme Management Unit, which falls under the Programme Management and Support Services Division.
20.136	The overall responsibilities of the executive direction and management component include the following functions:

(a)	To facilitate the debate among member States on the strategic direction of ECE and to develop a forward-looking strategy for adjusting ECE activities to respond to emerging and foreseeable priorities of its member States;
(b)	To provide guidance and direction for the work of the ECE secretariat, and to promote transparency and interdivisional cooperation;
(c)	To service meetings of the Commission and its Executive Committee and ensure the follow-up to their decisions;

(d)	To provide guidance and overall coordination of ECE programme management and evaluation, including under technical cooperation, and to promote the application of evaluation findings to the subprogrammes’ work;
(e)	To undertake regional policy reviews relating to major cross-sectoral issues, in particular sustainable development, gender, and the 2030 Agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals;
(f)	To contribute to increasing the visibility of ECE and to raising the awareness and use of ECE products through the dissemination of information about its activities;

(g)	To promote synergies and cooperation with other United Nations entities active in the ECE region, including with the resident coordinator system at the country level and the United Nations Sustainable Development Group for Europe and Central Asia at the regional level;
(h)	To foster and mainstream a gender perspective and disability inclusion into ECE subprogrammes;

(i)	To ensure effective financial, human and information and communications technology (ICT) resources management, as well as the implementation of recommendations of oversight bodies and internal controls.

20.137	The Office of the Executive Secretary, which includes the Executive Secretary, the Deputy Executive Secretary and the Secretary of the Commission, has the overall responsibility for providing policy guidance and leadership in the ECE secretariat, including the coordination of the work of the Commission; overseeing and developing relations with Governments; coordination with the United Nations Secretariat; reporting to the General Assembly and the Economic and Social Council; overseeing and developing relations with other United Nations entities and with non-United Nations organizations, civil society and non-governmental organizations; and mainstreaming a gender perspective across all subprogrammes through the development and implementation of the ECE gender policy and action plan and the gender parity strategy.

20.138	The Programme Management Unit, under the Programme Management and Support Services Division, provides guidance and ensures overall coordination of ECE programme management (planning, monitoring, reporting and evaluation). The Unit also ensures the follow-up to and implementation of the recommendations of United Nations oversight bodies, promotes synergies between the normative and operational work of ECE and provides guidance and overall coordination of technical cooperation. The Unit coordinates with other regional commissions and United Nations entities on programmatic and technical cooperation issues in support of the resident coordinator system countries within the ECE region.

20.139	The Sustainable Development Unit provides policy advice, analysis and advocacy on cross-cutting issues relating to the implementation of, follow-up on and review of the 2030 Agenda, in partnership with other United Nations entities and stakeholders, as relevant. The Unit convenes the annual Regional Forum on Sustainable Development for the ECE region, in cooperation with the entities of the regional United Nations system, providing the regional contribution to the global follow-up on and review of the 2030 Agenda. It plays a leading role in carrying out the functions of the regional collaborative platform, which gathers the heads of the regional offices for Europe and Central Asia of the United Nations entities. The Unit leads the internal work on the alignment of ECE activities with the Sustainable Development Goals through a cross-cutting approach.

20.140	The Information Unit is responsible for implementing the ECE information strategy aimed at raising awareness and mobilizing support for the work of ECE. The Unit manages ECE relations with the media, ensures the Commission’s presence on social media and provides related monitoring and analysis. It advises the Executive Secretary, senior managers and the staff of ECE on outreach and advocacy.

20.141	In 2026, the executive direction and management component will coordinate the planning of the ECE programme of work leading towards the 2027 session of the Commission and ensure monitoring of progress towards achieving planned results. In 2026 the annual exchange on evaluation will foster the use of evaluation results to improve programme planning and internal processes, which will be documented in the 2025 annual report on evaluation presented to the Executive Committee. To improve data quality and use, the component will guide and support, in cooperation with substantive divisions, the operationalization of the Data Strategy of the Secretary-General for Action by Everyone, Everywhere, based on the ECE ICT strategy and substantive divisions’ related action plans. The component will support the United Nations reform implementation and accelerated action for implementing the 2030 Agenda and the outcomes of the 2024 Sustainable Development Goals Summit and of the 2024 Summit of the Future, as applicable, by improving system-wide coherence and coordination of programme delivery at the regional and country levels. This will be done, among others, through the facilitation of the implementation of the 2026 workplan of the Regional Collaborative Platform for Europe and Central Asia, ensuring a successful meeting of the Regional Forum on Sustainable Development for the ECE Region and continuing active engagement in the 17 programme countries in partnership with resident coordinator offices and United Nations country teams, including in the preparation of United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, to be signed in 2026. Structured around the Goals, the 2025 technical cooperation report, to be presented to the Executive Committee, will include all the technical assistance provided to member States. The component will also continue to foster and mainstream a gender perspective by coordinating the implementation of the ECE gender action plan for 2025–2026, which will continue to act as the primary vehicle for implementation of the ECE policy for gender equality and the empowerment of women (2021–2025). In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, executive direction and management will continue to mainstream disability inclusion into ECE work, by reporting on the implementation of the ECE disability inclusion action plan for 2025 and planning for 2027.

20.142	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, ECE is integrating environmental management practices into its operations. ECE will continue to collaborate with the United Nations Office at Geneva on sustainability reporting and will highlight its sustainable practices in its formal reports.

20.143	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 20.29. The compliance rate of 97 per cent in 2024 for the timely submission of documentation relates to ECE meetings organized through the Division of Conference Management of the United Nations Office at Geneva and marks a slight increase compared with the prior period. The compliance rate of 71 per cent for air tickets purchased at least two weeks before the commencement of travel relates to all travel requests, including of staff, experts and consultants, and participants, the latter funded exclusively through extrabudgetary resources, processed by ECE in 2024 through the Travel and Logistics Unit of the United Nations Office at Geneva, and represents an increase when compared with 2023. ECE will continue to work closely with the travel and logistics counterparts on early planning to improve compliance rates in 2025 and 2026.

Programme support

20.153	The Programme Management and Support Services Division carries out activities related to programme planning, oversight, technical cooperation support, administration and common services such as budget and financial management, human resource management and information systems management and technology services for ECE. It also ensures compliance with organizational policies in these areas and liaises with United Nations Headquarters and the United Nations Office at Geneva, the designated service provider for ECE. The Division comprises the Office of the Director, which manages all aspects of programme planning, oversight and administration; the Programme Management Unit, under executive direction and management (explained in paragraph 20.138 above); and the Executive Office, which oversees and manages all aspects of administration, budget, finance, human resources and information systems.

20.154	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $3,614,600 and reflect an increase of $7,700 compared with the approved budget for 2025.
